name: Cardiology - Noninvasive

points: High clinic volume with limited time per patient; pressure to increase wRVUs
Backlogs for echo, stress imaging, and nuclear tests delay care and frustrate patients
Limited scanner time or sonographer staffing constrains throughput
Referral leakage to external imaging centers reduces continuity and revenue capture
Inpatient consults added on top of full clinic days
Frequent denials for advanced imaging (MPI, CCTA, CMR) despite indications
Time-consuming documentation to meet Appropriate Use Criteria and payer policies
Redundant testing risk when navigating multiple modalities
Administrative burden falls on physicians and APPs, impacting access and morale
Older ultrasound/nuclear equipment affecting image quality and interpretation confidence
Limited access to PET, CMR, or CCTA limits diagnostic options for complex cases
Inconsistent lab accreditation/QA processes (IAC/ASE) add friction
Fragmented PACS/reporting workflows slow turnaround and communication
Clinic + hospital responsibilities creep beyond scheduled hours
Unpredictable add-on studies and hospital consults disrupt family time
Documentation and inbox burden after hours
Desire for more predictable, outpatient-focused schedules
Underutilized APPs/sonographers leading to physician doing non-physician tasks
Ambiguity around hospital call expectations for a noninvasive role
Limited leadership pathway (e.g., echo/NM lab directorship) despite interest

motivations: More predictable outpatient schedule with limited/no inpatient call
Stronger imaging program (modern echo, stress, PET, CMR, CCTA) and reliable access
Efficient prior authorization support and AUC-aligned protocols
Leadership roles (Echo Lab Director, Nuclear Cardiology Director, Quality)
Improved compensation/bonus tied to realistic, supported productivity
Robust APP/sonographer staffing and triage workflows
Academic vs. community shift (teaching, research, protected time)
Equipment upgrades and committed capital for imaging growth
Defined clinic templates and protected interpretation time
Tele-cardiology options for follow-ups and chronic disease management
Clear pathway to partnership or long-term stability in health system employment

opening: Tell me about your current practice—outpatient vs. inpatient mix and a typical clinic day.
What’s driving you to explore new opportunities right now?
Help me understand the top things you’d like to change in your next role.
painDiscovery: You mentioned [challenge]. Walk me through how that shows up during a typical week.
Where do prior auth or AUC requirements create the biggest slowdowns for you?
How are imaging access and turnaround times affecting your patient care and schedule?
What parts of your day are spilling into evenings or weekends?
If you could change one process in your clinic or imaging lab tomorrow, what would it be?
clinical: Describe your scope: general cardiology, preventive clinics, HF/arrhythmia follow-up, device checks oversight?
What’s your typical clinic volume (new vs. follow-up) and desired daily census?
Imaging comfort: TTE/TEE, stress echo, SPECT/PET MPI, CMR, and CCTA interpretation—what’s in your wheelhouse?
How many studies do you interpret weekly today (echo, stress, nuclear), and what’s ideal?
Experience with lab accreditation (IAC/ASE) and QA protocols?
How do you prefer to structure protected reading time vs. clinic?
What hospital call/consult involvement (if any) is acceptable in a noninvasive role?
Any interest in program-building (preventive cardiology, lipid clinic, imaging service line)?
motivation: When you picture your ideal noninvasive practice, what does it look like day to day?
What would make a move clearly worthwhile for you and your family?
Rank your top three priorities: schedule, compensation, imaging resources, location, leadership, other?
What longer-term goals (directorship, teaching, research) matter to you?
compensation: Walk me through your current compensation: base, wRVU or collections bonus, stipends, and benefits.
What target compensation and structure (salary vs. wRVU) would feel right for your next role?
What’s driving your expectations—market data, current productivity, cost of living, or role scope?

commonChallenges.challenge: I want clinic-only with no hospital obligations.
commonChallenges.response: What level of inpatient exposure feels acceptable—e-consults only, rare weekend rounding, or strictly none? What trade-offs would you consider to secure that?

commonChallenges.challenge: Imaging access is too limited where I am.
commonChallenges.response: Which modalities are must-haves for you (PET, CMR, CCTA, stress echo), and how much weekly block time would make your practice work best?
Which studies generate the most denials? If we provide dedicated PA staff and AUC-aligned protocols, how would that change your day?

commonChallenges.challenge: Compensation needs to be at the top of market.
commonChallenges.response: Help me understand what’s driving that target and what mix of base vs. productivity, sign-on, and leadership stipends would make sense.

commonChallenges.challenge: I need modern equipment and better QA.
commonChallenges.response: Which upgrades (probes, software, PET/CMR access) and which quality metrics would signal the lab meets your standards?
What daily template and support ratio (APPs/sonographers) would balance quality and productivity for you?

challengingOpportunities: You mentioned wanting zero inpatient time. If we could wall off clinic + protected reading time with a light e-consult model, would that address the same need for predictability?
You prefer SPECT only—help me understand the underlying reason (access, comfort, accuracy). If PET or stress echo block time were guaranteed, would that meet the goal?
If prior auth is the main pain, what would dedicated PA coordinators + standardized AUC workflows unlock for your schedule and patient access?
You’re seeking a top-end base salary—if a balanced plan with leadership stipend, protected reading time, and reliable imaging access improves lifestyle, is that worth exploring?
